title: Paris Prosecutor’s News Conference on Paris Attacks, Live Video
content: François Molins, the Paris prosecutor, is giving a news briefing and you can watch live video, with translation, on France 24's website. He announced that the death toll from the coordinated attacks had risen to 129 people. There are as many as 300 people hospitalized, 99 in critical condition.

parent.title: Attacks in Paris: Live Updates From France

content_expanded:
François Molins, the Paris prosecutor, is giving a news briefing and you can watch live video, with translation, on France 24’s website.

He announced that the death toll from the coordinated attacks had risen to 129 people. There are as many as 300 people hospitalized, 99 in critical condition.

title: Arrests in Belgium May Have Link to Attacks
content: Koen Geens, the Belgian justice minister, said on Twitter that several arrests had been made in Brussels in connection with the Paris attacks. He told VRT, a Belgian public broadcasting network, that a black rental car with Belgian plates was found near the Bataclan concert hall, where about 80 people were killed on Friday night. On Saturday, the Belgian police carried out raids in the Molenbeek neighborhood of Brussels, near the Osseghem metro station, in an effort to find the person who had rented the car. "There have been several arrests made in Molenbeek related to a car found in Paris that is linked to the attacks," Sieghild Lacoere, a spokeswoman for the Belgian Ministry of Justice, said in a telephone interview. The car, she said, had been rented in Belgium. It was not clear whether any of the attackers were Belgian citizens.

parent.title: Attacks in Paris: Live Updates From France

content_expanded:
Koen Geens, the Belgian justice minister, said on Twitter that several arrests had been made in Brussels in connection with the Paris attacks.

He told VRT, a Belgian public broadcasting network, that a black rental car with Belgian plates was found near the Bataclan concert hall, where about 80 people were killed on Friday night.

On Saturday, the Belgian police carried out raids in the Molenbeek neighborhood of Brussels, near the Osseghem metro station, in an effort to find the person who had rented the car.

“There have been several arrests made in Molenbeek related to a car found in Paris that is linked to the attacks,” Sieghild Lacoere, a spokeswoman for the Belgian Ministry of Justice, said in a telephone interview. The car, she said, had been rented in Belgium.

It was not clear whether any of the attackers were Belgian citizens.

title: Bataclan Video Shows Victims Escaping Attack
content: [nytmedia id="100000004037762" crop="592" type="video" autostart="false"] In a video containing graphic images that some viewers may find disturbing, concertgoers at the Bataclan hall on Friday can be seen fleeing the attack there through a back door. Some of the people emptying into a Paris alleyway are visibly injured, and others can be seen dragging the limp bodies of their fellow concertgoers, leaving a crimson trail of blood. Another person escaping the attack can be seen hanging from a second-floor window. The video was shot by Daniel Psenny, a Le Monde journalist. On it, one person can be heard on the video asking, "What's going on?" Another can be heard fearfully saying, "Sir, sir, I am pregnant." A third implores: "Somebody needs to call the cops."

parent.title: Attacks in Paris: Live Updates From France

content_expanded:
Photo: Daniel Psenny/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images; Video: By LE MONDE and via REUTERS

In a video containing graphic images that some viewers may find disturbing, concertgoers at the Bataclan hall on Friday can be seen fleeing the attack there through a back door.

Some of the people emptying into a Paris alleyway are visibly injured, and others can be seen dragging the limp bodies of their fellow concertgoers, leaving a crimson trail of blood. Another person escaping the attack can be seen hanging from a second-floor window.

The video was shot by Daniel Psenny, a Le Monde journalist.

On it, one person can be heard on the video asking, “What’s going on?”

Another can be heard fearfully saying, “Sir, sir, I am pregnant.”

A third implores: “Somebody needs to call the cops.”

title: Germanwings Crash Responders at Stade de France During Attack
content: Hundreds of people directly touched by Europe's last major casualty were on hand Friday when terrorists carried out a deadly attack Friday near the Stade de France. Among the spectators in the crowd on Friday to watch the soccer match between France and Germany were hundreds of police officers, firefighters and other rescue workers who responded to the deadly crash of Germanwings Flight 9525 into a French mountainside. Heinz Joachim Schöttes, a Germanwings spokesman, confirmed that around 1,000 emergency workers were attending the soccer match as guests of the airline and its parent company, Lufthansa. Thomas Winkelmann, the Germanwings chief executive, as well as Carsten Spohr, the head of Lufthansa, were also in the stands, alongside Thomas Enders, the chief of Airbus Group. “At first we didn’t realize what was going on," said Rainer Ohler, head of communications for Airbus. "But then word went around from one participant to another. We all started getting messages on SMS and Twitter and what have you." The co-pilot of the Germanwings plane, Andreas Lubitz, intentionally plunged the Airbus 320 into a French mountainside, killing himself and all 149 other people on board.

parent.title: Attacks in Paris: Live Updates From France

content_expanded:
Hundreds of people directly touched by Europe’s last major casualty were on hand Friday when terrorists carried out a deadly attack Friday near the Stade de France.

Among the spectators in the crowd on Friday to watch the soccer match between France and Germany were hundreds of police officers, firefighters and other rescue workers who responded to the deadly crash of Germanwings Flight 9525 into a French mountainside.

Heinz Joachim Schöttes, a Germanwings spokesman, confirmed that around 1,000 emergency workers were attending the soccer match as guests of the airline and its parent company, Lufthansa. Thomas Winkelmann, the Germanwings chief executive, as well as Carsten Spohr, the head of Lufthansa, were also in the stands, alongside Thomas Enders, the chief of Airbus Group.

“At first we didn’t realize what was going on,” said Rainer Ohler, head of communications for Airbus. “But then word went around from one participant to another. We all started getting messages on SMS and Twitter and what have you.”

The co-pilot of the Germanwings plane, Andreas Lubitz, intentionally plunged the Airbus 320 into a French mountainside, killing himself and all 149 other people on board.

title: Somber Atmosphere at Amusement Park
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004037777" crop="190" type="image"]

At an amusement park halfway up the Champs Élysées boulevard, all the lights are off, except the ones at Jean-Louis Morel's 3D cinema. He’s trying to fix his.

"It's terrible," he said. "This is meant to be a place to enjoy yourself, but everyone here is sad."

Mr. Morel, 56, who owns the cinema, said he was here on the Champs Élysées when the Charlie Hebdo attacks happened in January. "It's the same atmosphere," he said. "There are very few people, and the people that are here are sad."

parent.title: Attacks in Paris: Live Updates From France

content_expanded:
At an amusement park halfway up the Champs Élysées boulevard, all the lights are off, except the ones at Jean-Louis Morel’s 3D cinema. He’s trying to fix his.

“It’s terrible,” he said. “This is meant to be a place to enjoy yourself, but everyone here is sad.”

Mr. Morel, 56, who owns the cinema, said he was here on the Champs Élysées when the Charlie Hebdo attacks happened in January. “It’s the same atmosphere,” he said. “There are very few people, and the people that are here are sad.”

title: Eagles of Death Metal Said to Cancel Rest of European Tour
content: Eagles of Death Metal, the American rock band that was playing at the Bataclan in Paris during the attacks on Friday night, has canceled the remainder of its European tour and is returning home, according to Agence France-Presse. The AFP quoted an unnamed representative of Nous Productions, a French concert promoter, as saying, "The group is going to return." The promoter did not say when. The band's tour had been scheduled to continue through Dec. 10 in Lisbon. Deftones, another American rock band that had been scheduled to play three shows at the Bataclan from Saturday through Monday, will also return home, according to the promoter. Deftones members were reported to have been at the Eagles of Death Metal concert on Friday, but the band said on its Facebook page that all its members and its crew were safe and accounted for. Representatives of Eagles of Death Metal have said that members of the band were safe, but a Facebook post from the band shortly after the attacks suggested that members of its crew were still unaccounted for.

parent.title: Attacks in Paris: Live Updates From France

content_expanded:
Eagles of Death Metal, the American rock band that was playing at the Bataclan in Paris during the attacks on Friday night, has canceled the remainder of its European tour and is returning home, according to Agence France-Presse.

The AFP quoted an unnamed representative of Nous Productions, a French concert promoter, as saying, “The group is going to return.” The promoter did not say when. The band’s tour had been scheduled to continue through Dec. 10 in Lisbon.

Deftones, another American rock band that had been scheduled to play three shows at the Bataclan from Saturday through Monday, will also return home, according to the promoter. Deftones members were reported to have been at the Eagles of Death Metal concert on Friday, but the band said on its Facebook page that all its members and its crew were safe and accounted for.

Representatives of Eagles of Death Metal have said that members of the band were safe, but a Facebook post from the band shortly after the attacks suggested that members of its crew were still unaccounted for.

title: Investigators Focus on Syrian Passport Found at Paris Attack Site
content:
Investigators are focusing on a Syrian passport discovered at the site of one of the terrorist attacks in Paris.

An official at the Greek Ministry of Public Order said on Saturday that the French authorities had asked the ministry to check  the number on the passport.

The minister of public order, Nikos Toskas, said that the holder of the passport is a Syrian who was registered on the island of Leros on Oct. 3, and that Greece sent the passport holder's fingerprint records to the French authorities for investigation.
An official at the Greek ministry said the passport was found on one of the bodies at the scene of one of the attacks.  But it was not clear if the holder of the passport was one of the attackers, a victim or connected in some other way to the attacks.

"The  holder of the passport passed through Leros on Oct. 3, 2015, and was identified on the basis of European Union rules, as they were decided at the leaders' summit on the refugee issue," he said in a statement. "We do not know if the passport was checked by other countries through which the holder may have passed." 

He added: "We will continue the painstaking and persistent effort under adverse conditions to secure the safety of our country and Europe, insisting on the full identification of those passing through as part of the refugee influx."

parent.title: Attacks in Paris: Live Updates From France

content_expanded:
Investigators are focusing on a Syrian passport discovered at the site of one of the terrorist attacks in Paris.

An official at the Greek Ministry of Public Order said on Saturday that the French authorities had asked the ministry to check the number on the passport.

The minister of public order, Nikos Toskas, said that the holder of the passport is a Syrian who was registered on the island of Leros on Oct. 3, and that Greece sent the passport holder’s fingerprint records to the French authorities for investigation.
An official at the Greek ministry said the passport was found on one of the bodies at the scene of one of the attacks. But it was not clear if the holder of the passport was one of the attackers, a victim or connected in some other way to the attacks.

“The holder of the passport passed through Leros on Oct. 3, 2015, and was identified on the basis of European Union rules, as they were decided at the leaders’ summit on the refugee issue,” he said in a statement. “We do not know if the passport was checked by other countries through which the holder may have passed.”

He added: “We will continue the painstaking and persistent effort under adverse conditions to secure the safety of our country and Europe, insisting on the full identification of those passing through as part of the refugee influx.”

title: Foo Fighters Joins U2 in Canceling Paris Show
content:
The Foo Fighters said on Saturday that they had canceled the remainder of their European tour in response to the attacks, joining U2 to become the second major act to abandon plans to perform in Paris
It is with profound sadness and heartfelt concern for everyone in Paris that we have been forced to announce the cancellation of the rest of our tour. In light of this senseless violence, the closing of borders, and international mourning, we can't continue right now.
It continued, "Our thoughts and prayers are with everyone who was hurt or who lost a loved one." The band was scheduled to play in Turin, Italy, on Saturday; Paris on Monday; and Lyon, France, on Tuesday.

parent.title: Attacks in Paris: Live Updates From France

content_expanded:
The Foo Fighters said on Saturday that they had canceled the remainder of their European tour in response to the attacks, joining U2 to become the second major act to abandon plans to perform in Paris

It is with profound sadness and heartfelt concern for everyone in Paris that we have been forced to announce the cancellation of the rest of our tour. In light of this senseless violence, the closing of borders, and international mourning, we can’t continue right now.

It continued, “Our thoughts and prayers are with everyone who was hurt or who lost a loved one.”

The band was scheduled to play in Turin, Italy, on Saturday; Paris on Monday; and Lyon, France, on Tuesday.

title: Parade Fireworks in London Are Called Off
content: On Saturday, London celebrated Lord Mayor's Day — an annual event dating to 1215 that includes a river pageant, a carnival street parade and elaborate fireworks over the Thames. But in light of the terrorist attacks in Paris, the organizers decided to cancel the fireworks that would have ended the celebration. “It is time for a show of solidarity with the victims of an atrocious terrorist attack and not a time for celebrations,” the organizers announced on Twitter. Red, white and blue lights — the colors of the French Republic — will shine on the Tower Bridge, in solidarity with the victims of the attacks, the organizers said. Lord Mayor’s Day honors the day King John issued a Royal Charter in 1215 that allowed the City of London — the municipal corporation that governs what is now London's financial district — to elect its own lord mayor. As a condition, however, the newly elected mayor had to travel to Westminster to pledge allegiance to the Crown. This journey, which starts on the Thames, has been re-enacted every year since 1215 despite wars, plagues and fires. The event, sometimes described as “the world’s oldest street party,” is one of the biggest in London and draws large crowds along the Thames and in the city itself.

parent.title: Attacks in Paris: Live Updates From France

content_expanded:
On Saturday, London celebrated Lord Mayor’s Day — an annual event dating to 1215 that includes a river pageant, a carnival street parade and elaborate fireworks over the Thames.

But in light of the terrorist attacks in Paris, the organizers decided to cancel the fireworks that would have ended the celebration.

“It is time for a show of solidarity with the victims of an atrocious terrorist attack and not a time for celebrations,” the organizers announced on Twitter.

Red, white and blue lights — the colors of the French Republic — will shine on the Tower Bridge, in solidarity with the victims of the attacks, the organizers said.

Lord Mayor’s Day honors the day King John issued a Royal Charter in 1215 that allowed the City of London — the municipal corporation that governs what is now London’s financial district — to elect its own lord mayor.

As a condition, however, the newly elected mayor had to travel to Westminster to pledge allegiance to the Crown. This journey, which starts on the Thames, has been re-enacted every year since 1215 despite wars, plagues and fires.

The event, sometimes described as “the world’s oldest street party,” is one of the biggest in London and draws large crowds along the Thames and in the city itself.
